description.narrative: The accelerated HCFC phase-out achieved in compliance with objectives 2020 within the Montreal Protocol and sustainably reduced the servicing tail.

participating-org.narrative: Republican Research Centre of Emergency Medicine

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

provider-org.narrative: Republican Research Centre of Emergency Medicine

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

comment.narrative:
Target 1: 1.3.5 One information exchange event that supported the State Customs Cooperation to improve the information exchange and interaction with counterparts in other countries in the region.
Target 2: 2.2.5 One thematic discussion with RAC technologies users on application of zero-ODS low GWP alternative technologies conducted 2.4.4 One networking and experience exchange with foreign counterparts from the CEIT region conducted
Target 3: 3.1.1 One information materials developed 3.1.2 One awareness raising activity implemented
Target 4 4.2.a) Regular monitoring and evaluation of the project activities and results conducted and presented during Project Board meetings, which organized twice in a year and serve as guidance to project’s implementation plan.

1.3.5 A practical study tour to the Central Customs Laboratory of Istanbul, Turkey in Istanbul conducted during 4-7 December 2017 by specialists of the State Customs Committee of the Republic of Uzbekistan and a representative of the State Committee of the Republic of Uzbekistan for Ecology and Environmental Protection to exchange experience and study best international practices on import/export of ozone depleting substances (ODS), their alternatives and equipment containing ODS. The specialists of the State Customs Committee strengthened their knowledge about and learned on how to develop gas standards for mass spectrometer from the Istanbul Customs Laboratory experts; Customs of Uzbekistan and Turkey agreed to sign MoU for cooperation.
2.2.5 Thematic discussions held with the representatives of korzinka.uz ( Anglesey Food ), LLC “Khiva Maishiy Texnika”, LLC “O’zpromholodmontaj” and “Uzbekoziqovqatzahira” Association and 100 representatives of the project partner’s network (virtually) organized.
2.4.4 The representatives of Goscomecology and UNDP participated and delivered presentation in the Regional Ozone Network for Europe & Central Asia (ECA network) of UNEP` OzonAction Programme on enforcement and implementation of the Montreal Protocol to reduce the consumption and production of HCFCs and the Kigali Amendment to reduce HFCs in Kyev, Ukraine, during 24-27 September 2019.
3.1.1 One pager of the project developed, printed and disseminated; One article developed and published in magazine on Kigali Amendment application in Uzbekistan; Infographics on how to choose home air conditioners developed.
3.1.2 Visit to the 31st Meeting of Parties of the Montreal Protocol to share best practices on the Ozone layer protection of Uzbekistan and to nominate Tashkent for hosting the 32nd MOP in 2020 conducted; During the MOP 31, Uzbekistan’s experience on application of zero-ODS and low-GWP technology in social building (hospital) showcased; The awareness-raising campaign: a contest in four categories and a lecture about the Ozone layer preservation dedicated to the celebration of the International Day for the Preservation of the Ozone Layer organized in September 2019.
4.2.a) Three monitoring visits conducted to the project sites. The results were presented during the Project Board meeting.

Target 1: Target 1.1.2 National survey of consumption of HFCs and other alternative cooling agents (natural cooling agents) and their uses undertaken for government to consider the impact of the Kigali Amendment on phase out of HFCs. Target 1.2.1 Two proposals to upgrade legislation prepared and provided to the National Partners consideration, and accepted Target 1.3.1 Central Customs Laboratory provided with, at least, ten (10) samples of 5 types of refrigerant’ standards for calibrating their gas chromatographs and updating software. Target 1.3.2: At least 50 importers and environmental inspectors, including, at least, 30% women, trained, and improved their knowledge on the use of a newly introduced electronic systems of declaring ODS/ODS alternatives import/export. Target 1.3.3: Extended capacity of the State Customs Committee of centralized storage of seized smuggled ODS/ODS alternatives is available
Target 2: Target 2.1.1 Established Six (6) new (4 recycling and 2 reclaim) and upgraded six (6) operating (5 recycling and 1 reclaim) centers Target 2.1.4 100 public and private enterprises of the RAC sector benefited from project interventions in terms of servicing tools supplies Target 2.1.5 Six newly established and six existing HCFC re-use centers able to develop technical/business plans to ensure sustainability of operations over longer term Target 2.2.1 One demonstration project implemented in public facilities/ commercial applications/ training centers Target 2.2.4 5 refrigeration technicians that improved knowledge to assemble, install, operate and maintain zero-ODS low GWP Target 2.2.5 One thematic discussion with RAC technologies users on application of zero-ODS low GWP alternative technologies conducted Target 2.4.1 Three vocational training centers established and equipped in the regions of Uzbekistan Target 2.4.4 One networking and experience exchange with foreign counterparts from the CEIT region conducted
Target 3: Target 3.1.1 Four information materials developed Target 3.1.2 1 awareness raising activity implemented Target 3.2.3 A comprehensive resource mobilization strategy developed
Target 4: Target 4.1.1 Two start-up businesses of women supported that ensured higher job placement rate for women studying RAC sector related business Target 4.1.3 A comprehensive survey conducted, and its results are available Target 4.2 a) Regular monitoring and evaluation of the project activities and results conducted and presented during Project Board meetings, which organized twice in a year and serve as guidance to project’s implementation plan. Target 4.1.b) KM products prepared throughout the project implementation on its achievements to inform wider audience in the country and in regional and international meetings

Target 1.1.2: Data on sectoral use of ODS and ODS alternatives collected for the period of 2010-2020 (first half); Feasibility and implications study of ratification of Kigali amendment for the Republic of Uzbekistan conducted
Target 1.2.1: Inputs to drafting resolution of the Cabinet of Ministers on “National program on Complete ODS phase-out” and the resolutions roadmap provided and included: 1. Establishment of the National Refrigeration and Air-Conditioning (RAC) Association to support the government in the development of relevant legislation, industry wide data gathering for effective decision-making and implementation of RAC relevant policies and state programmes; 2. Inclusion of four project activities to the Roadmap of the Resolution: (i) Support in enhancement of national legislation, including assessment of the Kigali Amendments ratification; capacity building of Customs and enforcement officers on the control of HCFCs and ODS alternatives during import/export; (ii) Strengthening the HCFC re-use system and implementation of demonstration projects on HCFC replacement with ODS-free/low GWP alternatives; (iii) Information exchange within the industries and awareness raising among stakeholders; (iv) Attracting women to RAC sector through education, new business skills. The draft Resolution, along with the roadmap, is currently under discussion at the President office.
Target 1.3.1: Staff of the Uzbek State Customs Laboratory learned on how to develop a sample standard for gas chromatograph calibration by several equipment which are available their Laboratory from the Istanbul Central Customs Laboratory colleagues within the study tour organized by project team. This avoided the need of sample standards procurement for calibration of gas chromatograph.
Target 1.3.2: 188 participants (8 females) trained in detection of ODS in export-import operations and on e-validation of the import of goods/cooling agents through newly introduced online platform Single Window within the online scientific/practical workshop conducted on 14 September 2020.
Target 1.3.3: Inputs provided to development of the Parties document with technical specifications of the equipment for establishment of the centralized storage of seized smuggled ODS/ODS alternatives developed with the State Customs Committee; corresponding procurement (forklift, pallet rackings, euro-pallets and repairing services) done, except forklift which delivery is scheduled for the end of December 2020.
Target 2.1.1: Technical documentation (ToR) for establishing of two (2) Reclaim and four (4) Recycle centers and additional equipment for existing one (1) Reclaim center and six (5) Recycle centers finalized; and equipment with tools procured; equipment and tools for temporary use will be transferred to the end-users by the end 2020.
Target 2.1.4: RAC equipment spare parts for one hundred (100) public and private enterprises procured; spare parts will be transferred to the end-users by the end 2020.
Target 2.1.5: 14 participants (one female) represented management and personnel of Recycle/Reclaim centers skilled to develop business plans through training within online workshops conducted in October 2020; Business plans aimed at ensuring sustainability of eleven recovery and recycling centers available.
Target 2.2.1: Technical documentation (contribution of parties with technical specification) for the demonstration project with LLC “Khiva Maishiy Texnika” on application of zero-ODS, low-GWP and energy efficient technology developed; Equipment and tools for the demonstration project with LLC “Khiva Maishiy Texnika” procured; and will be transferred for temporary use by the end-users by the end 2020.
Target 2.2.4: Training for users/operators after implementation of energy-efficient, zero-ODS and low-GWP technologies designed but postponed due to UN restrictions release for travels during COVID-19 pandemic.
Target 2.2.5: 7 representatives of RAC sector companies and independent experts participated in online technical/thematic discussions during February-April 2020. Relevant proposals for improvement of RAC sector collected and analyzed.
Target 2.4.1: Technical documentation (contribution of parties with technical specification of equipment) for establishing three training centers developed; Equipment and tools (except for CO2 Heat pump) procured and will be transferred for temporary use by the end-users by the end 2020.
Target 2.4.4: Sharing of experience on implementation of new Regional Project on Kigali Amendment and implementation of demo project on R290 split air-conditioners as well as on R290 monoblocs done (virtually) and technical documents shared with UNDP Tajikistan colleagues.
Target 3.1.1: Communication strategy 2020-24 developed; Two animation clips for kids and public audience developed in three languages (Uzbek, Russian and Karakalpak) with English subtitles; One infographics for kids produced; Three e-banners: contest announcement for celebration of World Ozone Day, contest for selection of demonstration projects and banner for World Ozone Day event produced; Four types of promo materials: powerbank, umbrealla, eco-bag and USB stick produced; 4000 kids’ poster printed for awareness raising campaign printed; diploma and certificates for the winners of the World Ozone Day contest printed;
Target 3.1.2: 192 participants (46 females) participated in 10-day online contest (in the form of quiz) on the occasion of the World Environment Day encouraging for action on the protection of the Ozone Layer; Online Contest in three categories devoted to World Ozone Day conducted and resulted in receipt of 22 poems, 28 videoclips and 18 articles; Media coverage of Uzbekistan participation in COP12/MOP32 done in November 2020; Media coverage of Project Board Meeting done on 3 December 2020.
Target 3.2.3: International expert for resource mobilization strategy recruited; a resource mobilization strategy for RAC sector will be completed by the end 2020.
Target 4.1.1 This activity was postponed to the next year due to COVID-19 related UN and local restrictions for people gathering and travel, as it is closely linked to a PR campaign and results of the gender survey/roadmap.
Target 4.1.3 Despite the pandemic restrictions on the collection of survey participants in person, the gender survey aimed at identification of barriers to attract women into the RAC sector conducted via telegram messenger: in total, 3233 participants from mahallas (849 women and 353 men), institutes/universities (297 women and 752 men), professional schools (333 women and 575 men) and the project’s partner RAC companies (9 women and 65 men) in all regions of Uzbekistan; and the survey’s findings formulated, recommendations on gender mainstreaming presented and developed RoadMap to attract women to RAC sector will be sent for government (State Committee for Ecology and Environmental Protection) consideration; developed recommendations and roadmap for gender mainstreaming in project activities will be implemented during project implementation.
Target 4.2 a) Regular online monitoring conducted, and results were presented during the Project Board meeting held on 3 December 2020; Data on use of ODS and their alternatives for the first, second and third quarters of 2020 collected from 100 private and public companies.
Target 4.1.b) Project results and relevant knowledge management products are carefully collected for wider dissemination.

Target 1 1.2.1 Two proposals to upgrade legislation prepared and provided to the National Partners consideration, and accepted 1.2.2 Two proposals on recovery and recycling and proper dismantling and disposal of equipment containing ODS developed and provided for Government consideration 1.3.4 One set of special equipment, including office inventory and training materials/identification equipment provided to Customs Services for better control over HCFC movement and phase-out. 1.3.5 One information exchange event that supported the State Customs Cooperation to improve the information exchange and interaction with counterparts in other countries in the region.
Target 2 Target 2.1.1 Established Six (6) new (4 recycling and 2 reclaim) and upgraded six (6) operating (5 recycling and 1 reclaim) centers Target 2.1.2 1,000 kg HCFCs recycled and 200 kg reclaimed Target 2.1.4 100 public and private enterprises of the RAC sector benefited from project interventions in terms of servicing tools supplies Target 2.2.1 Two demonstration project implemented in public facilities/ commercial applications/ training centers Target 2.2.4 Ten refrigeration technicians that improved knowledge to assemble, install, operate and maintain zero-ODS low GWP
Target 3 Target 3.1.1 Five information materials developed Target 3.1.2 One awareness raising and two networking activities implemented Target 3.2.3 A comprehensive resource mobilization strategy developed
Target 4 4.1.1 Two start-up businesses of women supported that ensured higher job placement rate for women studying RAC sector related business. 4.1.4 One partnership agreement signed and two (2) joint activities with partners conducted 4.2 a) Regular monitoring and evaluation of the project activities and results conducted and presented during Project Board meetings, which organized once a year and serve as guidance to project’s implementation plan. 4.2 b) KM products prepared throughout the project implementation on its achievements to inform wider audience in the country and in regional and international meetings.

TARGET 1 1.2.2 Two proposals on recovery and recycling and proper dismantling and disposal of equipment containing ODS developed and provided for Government consideration 1.3.2 Twenty five (25) importers and environmental inspectors, including, at least, 30% women, trained, and improved their knowledge on the use of a newly introduced electronic systems of declaring ODS/ODS alternatives import/export 1.3.5 One information exchange event that supported the State Customs Cooperation to improve the information exchange and interaction with counterparts in other countries in the region. 1.4 One joint event aimed at increasing an institutional capacity of environmental officers implemented
TARGET 2 Target 2.1.2 1,000 kg HCFCs recycled and 300 kg reclaimed Target 2.1.4 100 public and private enterprises of the RAC sector benefited from project interventions in terms of servicing tools supplies Target 2.2.1 Three demonstration projects implemented in public facilities/ commercial applications/ training centers Target 2.2.2 One comprehensive awareness raising event on benefits of new technologies organized; and at least one mutually beneficial partnership with other-than-GEF funding sources established Target 2.2.4 Ten refrigeration technicians that improved knowledge to assemble, install, operate and maintain zero-ODS low GWP Target 2.2.5 One thematic discussion with RAC technologies users on application of zero-ODS low GWP alternative technologies conducted Target 2.3.1 One facility equipped with HCFC based equipment performance monitoring system and used with regular reporting on results established Target 2.4.3 100 technicians trained, and skills upgraded on low GWP technologies with online and 50 with onsite training programmes Target 2.4.4 One networking and experience exchange with foreign counterparts from the CEIT region conducted
TARGET 3 Target 3.1.1 Four information materials developed, and one study launched on learning from outreach activities in other regions and apply best practices in Uzbekistan Target 3.1.2 At least one awareness raising activities implemented Target 3.2.1 One local/international donor engaged to promote modern HCFC-free and low GWP RAC technologies on wider scale Target 3.2.3 A comprehensive resource mobilization strategy developed and presented with at least 1 donor engaged in technical assistance and/or provided loan to increase application of advanced technologies in RAC sector 3.2.4 One enterprise engages with the new financial mechanisms (bilateral, international or private sector funding sources) during the project duration
TARGET 4 4.1.2 One women-students receiving the stipend scheme to study RAC in the technical and vocational education institutions 4.1.4 One partnership agreements signed and two (2) joint activities with partners conducted 4.2 a) Regular monitoring and evaluation of the project activities and results conducted and presented during Project Board meetings, which organized once a year and serve as guidance to project’s implementation plan. 4.2 b) KM products prepared throughout the project implementation on its achievements to inform wider audience in the country and in regional and international meetings.
